Description: In this immersive masterclass on translating short stories, participants embark on a captivating journey into the world of literary translation. Led by literary translator, Gaia Baldassarri, the class focuses on the technicalities of translating short stories, a genre that requires skillful precision and cultural sensitivity. Through an exploration of diverse narrative styles, themes, and voices, participants learn how to convey the essence of the story while infusing it with richness and authenticity in the target language. The masterclass introduces participants to the tools needed to handle linguistic nuances and cultural references in a seamless manner. By honing their understanding of character development, plot structure, and literary devices, attendees are equipped to craft compelling translations that resonate with readers. Engaging in practical exercises, participants work collectively to refine their translation skills and develop their own unique style.  Whether you are an aspiring translator seeking to enter the world of literary translation or an experienced linguist looking to enhance your expertise, this masterclass promises to deepen your appreciation for the art of translating short stories and provide you with the knowledge and confidence to create impactful translations that transcend borders and cultures. TÔªøranslators working with any language pair are welcome. The session is delivered in English. It is only available to attend in-person. Short stories are brief, fictional narrative prose pieces that typically focus on a single incident, character, or theme. They are much shorter than novels, often only one or two pages long, and often centre on a single plotline or moment in the lives of its characters.  Short stories can be found in a wide range of genres and styles, and are known for their concise and compact storytelling, aiming to convey a complete and impactful narrative within a limited word count. The brevity of short stories allows writers to explore themes, emotions, and character development in an engaging way. However, balancing tone and style, cultural context and pacing with the brevity of the medium can make translating short stories more challenging than it might appear.  Before the masterclass takes place, attendees will be sent a short story which will be the focus of the workshop. Together, we will look at everyone's translations of the story. People who have signed up to attend will be sent a link to the story and to upload their translations before the session. These translations will be shared with everyone else in the group and serve as the basis for part of the masterclass. Gaia Baldassarri is a Dublin-based literary translator and visual artist. She holds a BA in Languages, Literatures and Intercultural Studies (Scandinavian and German studies) awarded by the University of Florence, and an MPhil in Literary Translation from Trinity College Dublin. Her translation interests include cultural specificity and dialects especially in contemporary Irish and Italian fiction.
Organizer: Trinity Centre for Literary & Cultural Translation
Title: Translation Masterclass: Short Stories with Gaia Baldassarri
Subtitle: Join Literary Translator, Gaia Baldassarri, for an interactive workshop on translating short stories

Description: TISH Directed by PaulSng (English / 90mins) WATCH TRAILER Tish Murtha was a visionary photographer committed to documenting the struggle and inequality of the working-class communities that framed her upbringing. Her archive of work from Northeast England and London‚Äôs Soho in the 1970s and 1980s is lovingly realised in this exploration of the legacy of her work and private life by her daughter, Ella Murtha. As a working class photographer from the North East, Tish felt an obligation to the people and problems within her local environment, and used documentary photography to highlight and challenge the social disadvantages she herself suffered. Unlike many social documentary photographers, Tish was from the same streets as the people she photographed, lending a poignant intimacy to her stark yet tender black and white images. However, despite early acclaim for her work, she was unable to make a living from photography and was unable to escape the poverty she documented. She died aged 56, her work relatively unknown. Tish‚Äôs brilliant eye, her unswerving ethics and constant empathy are present in her images, yet little is known of the artist herself. In this feature documentary we follow Tish‚Äôs daughter, Ella, as she opens up her mother‚Äôs archive for the first time on screen to reveal a treasure trove of unseen images, artefacts, letters and diaries. Ella takes to the road to meet people who knew Tish and ask why she did not receive more recognition in her lifetime. In digging into the past, Ella comes to terms with her own grief at her mother‚Äôs passing and reconnects with family members not seen in years. By shining a light on a working class artist who went largely unrecognised in her lifetime, the documentary questions the value placed on working class people both in the past and present day.
Title: TISH (feature documentary)
Subtitle: A film about social documentary photographer TISH MURTHA, who photographed the working class communities in England in the 1970's & 1980's.

Description: Living Freedom ‚ÄòUniversity Salons‚Äô are for all students (and academics) keen to explore and debate ideas on the past, present and future of freedom. A short talk is followed by plenty of time for questions and discussion. Everyone is welcome to come along. TOPICFrom Hate Speech to Misinformation: Why Social Media is Not the Problem With digital culture and myriad forms of social media, each of us can share more information and opinions more widely than ever before. Today every individual has a personalised channel, social network and algorithms that shape what they want to see next. But many worry that productive exchanges of ideas have diminished, along with potential to develop a shared worldview and even a shared reality. New identity driven forms of polarisation, hate speech, online harms and fake news fuel fears that the very technologies that transformed communications are responsible for our descent into echo chambers, toxic filter bubbles and the demonising of those with whom we disagree. With Taoiseach Leo Varadkar claiming incitement to hatred legislation is ‚Äúnot up to date for the social media age‚Äù many worry that a planned new hate crime law will have a grave impact on free speech. But to what extent are new digital technologies really the problem? After all, just over a decade ago, social media was celebrated for the power to share ideas and drive political change in the Arab Spring. In this talk followed by open discussion, Timandra Harkness explores both the new digital technologies and the new identity driven forms of culture and politics, and asks: how did we get here, why does it matter and where do we go from here? Instead of pointing the finger at the smartphone and new technologies, do we need to understand our own our shrinking sense of who we are and obsession with how others see us? --------------------- SPEAKER: TIMANDRA HARKNESSjournalist, writer and broadcaster; author, Technology is Not the Problem (2024)Timandra Harkness is author of Technology is Not the Problem (forthcoming, Harper Collins). She is also author of Big Data: does size matter? Timandra is a regular on BBC Radio, writing and presenting BBC Radio 4‚Äôs FutureProofing and other series including How To Disagree, Steelmanning and Political School. BBC documentaries include Data, Data Everywhere, Divided Nation, What Has Sat-Nav Done To Our Brains, and Five Knots. She was also resident reporter on all eight seasons of social psychology series The Human Zoo. Timandra is a graduate fellow of the Royal Statistical Society, and a founder member of their Data Ethics and Governance Section. She has written for publications including the Telegraph, Guardian, The Sunday Times, Men‚Äôs Health and Significance (the journal of the Royal Statistical Society). CHAIR: ALASTAIR DONALDconvenor, Living Freedom

Subtitle: Timandra Harkness, author of 'Technology is Not the Problem', introduces the discussion.

Description: Peacebuilding, the Arts and the Participation of Children and Young People Tuesday 12th March 2024, 12 - 4pm Senate Room, Queen‚Äôs University Belfast Organised by Dr. Edel Lamb and Professor Fiona Magowan This event hosted by the Senator George J. Mitchell Institute for Global Peace, Security and Justice will bring together practitioners and researchers working with and on children and young people to explore the contribution of children and young people‚Äôs participation in the creative arts to peacebuilding. It will explore questions such as how the creative arts can facilitate the expression of children‚Äôs and young people‚Äôs experiences of conflict and post-conflict societies; does it empower them to participate in processes of social justice, transformation and commemoration; and how can listening to children‚Äôs creative productions across diverse cultural contexts help us better understand the contribution they have made and can make to peacebuilding, historically, now and in the future? It welcomes perspectives from across the creative arts (including literature, film, theatre, dance, visual arts, music), from across historical and cultural contexts, and broad definitions of children and young people for an exploratory discussion to identify shared research questions, challenges and practices with the aim of establishing connections for a future research network. The afternoon will include a networking lunch, brief presentations, and a roundtable discussion. Attendance is free but please register in advance as spaces will be limited. If you have any questions please contact Edel Lamb (e.lamb@qub.ac.uk) or Fiona Magowan (f.magowan@qub.ac.uk).

Description: Would you love to learn how to use a sewing machine and start making your own clothes and accessories? Maybe you want to alter, revamp, or make lovely things for your home? This is the perfect course for you, as you will learn to sew on a machine from scratch in a beautiful fashion design studio in Conway Mill, Belfast. The tutor is studio owner MaryRose McGrath - a womenswear designer with 25 years in the fashion industry. During her career, she has designed for many brands, including Oasis, M&S, Debenhams, Arcadia, House Of Fraser and more. You will be taught the sewing techniques used in the industry - also included are many more nifty tips and tricks of the trade, which guarantee superb sewing results every time. During class, you will be surrounded by inspiration galore in the studio - actual designs in work, fabrics, mood boards, mannequins & sketches. One-to-one tuition is also guaranteed for each student in class, and the course has been specifically designed to fast-track your sewing success in a concentrated period of time. All this means you will advance from a nervous novice to a confident maker by the end of the two evenings. For past student feedback, see our fantastic course reviews below....... LEARN THE FOLLOWING: * What machine should you choose if buying one? Top tips & recommendations. * An easy-to-understand explanation of the sewing machines confusing dials & knobs, what each does * How to thread the machine correctly - learn about threads and why your choice matters * How to wind the bobbin properly * How to sew with precision - how to achieve perfect seams each time * Seam allowances & why they matter in sewing & alterations * Fitting garments- a full explanation of beginner fitting techniques and why ease matters when altering garments. * How to hem a garment * How to take in or let out seams * How to sew darts to add shaping to a garment TWO EVENINGS OF IN-DEPTH SEWING TUITION , PLUS THE USE OF A BROTHER SEWING MACHINE & ALL OUR PROFESSIONAL EQUIPMENT. ALL FABRICS & THREADS ARE INCLUDED. Where is the course held? The course is held in MaryRose's fashion design studio in Conway Mill, Belfast. The address is Conway Mill, 5-7 Conway Street, Belfast BT13 2DE. Who is the course suitable for? This course is perfect for absolute beginners who have never used a sewing machine before and haven't a clue where to start - it is also ideal for those who have not sewn in years and need a refresher course to get back on track. Garment alterations are covered too, so the course is suited for those who want to tailor their clothes for a better fit. What age do you have to be to take part in the class? Classes are for ages 18+. Young sewers aged 12+ are also welcome if they are accompanied by a parent/guardian who is also booked on the course. Do I need to bring a sewing machine with me? No need - we supply excellent Brother sewing machines for all students in class. What do I need to bring with me? We supply your machine, fabrics and threads, however, you will need to bring the following: * Reading glasses if you need them for close-up work * A notebook and pen for all the notes and important info you will be taught in class. How many students are in the class? Eight students maximum are in the class. We specifically keep classes small to ensure you get lots of one-to-one tuition with MaryRose during the course - the ultimate way to learn. How much does the course cost? The course includes 6 hours of intensive sewing tuition (4 classes over two evenings), the use of the design studio, practice fabrics & threads and a Brother sewing machine to learn on. The course cost is ¬£99. How do I book the course? You can book this course here through Eventbrite using PayPal. Eventbrite charges a booking fee. OR You can book the course through the studio, with no booking fee added. Please e-mail your contact details to: info@maryrosemcgrath.com, or call 02895 215683 to book through the studio. We take payment by card over the phone - this confirms your booking. I can't make this date - are there any other dates available for this course? Yes, the other dates available to book are: Saturday 2nd March - all day course Sunday 10th March - all day course Saturday 20th April - all day course See all class listings on Eventbrite. WHERE TO MEET BEFORE CLASS STARTS: The studio is closed before class, and doors open at 6.15 pm. MaryRose will collect all students from Conway Mill reception on the ground floor at 6.10 pm and take you to the studio on the second floor. ( Please do not try and find the studio as you may get lost ). Is there any other important information I should know before booking a space on the course? PLEASE READ THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF BOOKING BELOW : 1. Late arrivals: There is a huge amount to learn in the course- late arrivals disrupt students, the tutor and the teaching schedule. Late arrivals of 15 minutes or more are not accepted into class as it is impossible to recap after this time. 2. Non-attendance: Due to the small number of students in class & the niche nature of this course, refunds / a new beginners course on another date/credit notes or vouchers are not provided if the student has not attended any part of the course for any reason including : Covid/covid isolation/ illness / unexpected circumstances or events/ transport / personal circumstances / other. 3: Transfer the booking to another person if you can not attend: If you can not make the course (including covid/covid isolation/illness / unexpected circumstances or events /transport/ personal circumstances / other), you can transfer the name - so someone else attends the course in your place. To transfer a name, call us a minimum of 24 hours before the course starts to inform us of the name change. Please ensure you call us during office hours from Tuesday to Friday, 9 am to 5.00 pm. The studio telephone number is 02895 215683. * Please note that e-mails or social media messages are not accepted to transfer the name of a person attending class. 4. Course cancellation: On rare occasions, classes may have to be cancelled due to unforeseen circumstances. We will inform students immediately by e-mailing & calling. You will be offered a refund, a transfer to another date, or a credit note. Please note we are not liable for any costs incurred. 5. Speed of learning: Progress and speed of learning depends on each student's natural abilities during class. 6.
